I've been on the fence about trying one of these since they were announced, but finally took advantage of the sale and thought maybe it could be a nice replacement for my home theater sound. Well, setup was nice and easy, and the demo sounded great. Although I did note that in order to REALLY get the effect you have to have it center screen. Which means if I keep this I'm going to have to raise my television a few more inches so this behemoth doesn't get in the way. But I would do that...if it worked. I've had it 3 days, used it 2, had to reset it and set it back up at least 7 times so far. Most because I have 2 wifi connections in my home (one for me and one for guests), and although I set this up with the main one and NEVER gave it the password for the guest wifi, it's already in Amazon so it kept switching over. And there is no way in the app or anywhere else to change wifi connections without wiping it and starting over fresh. This happened even after I went in and told Amazon to forget the guest wifi altogether. It's also just come disconnected from the Echo Cube randomly, resulting in having to go into the app and unpair and repair the home theater setup. I haven't made it through a single movie yet without it having to be reset. Sound is great, as long as you have it centered. The home theater is great - when it works. Also disappointed that it won't work with my other echos, but I just wish I could get it to stay consistently connected to the Echo Cube.

i now have purchased 3 of these studio speakers-PRO'S- got them on holiday sale 150 each-sound very good-easy to talk too unlike my wife haha. has both wifi and Bluetooth-CON'S-no ip rating so no water resistant's- not that easy to pair together- seems like pairing for fire tv only. doesn't pair for Bluetooth only Wi-Fi so if talking to Alexa for music will stereo pair. trying to get tv to pair both speakers is harder than it should be . only one still works on mine will keep trying.- having more than 1 Alexa device is a pain because you need to give them different names or other ones hear you and start playing. unless far away from each other. but they seem to hear you from a good distance but that could be a plus or minus for you. and yes a bit creepy. more info will come as i get to know more about Alexa. hope i don't need a divorce from Alexa or wife haha. good luck. P.S. sonos1 has better cleaner sound but no Bluetooth that was a deal breaker. and i hate the sonos app. i just want to play whatever is on my phone without sonos in my way. simple as that. hope someone in sonos reads this. good luck.

I was excited about the hype behind the Echo Studio and the technology looked great. But for me it was a bit disappointing sound wise from what I was expecting. The sound separation was not as good as just a simple left end right speaker set up. The bass at set levels was lacking so I needed to adjust that in the app. Even with the Ultra HD Amazon music songs and Dolby Atmos movies, there wasn't a lot of blow you away-ism.
A bothersome thing was that in the app they have a setting to pair the Echo Studio with a remote. I thought this would be very helpful because I have an Echo Show 8 next to were I sit and to voice activate the Studio with the remote would save some "alexa" confusion. Also it would be good to use the volume controls on the remote for the speaker. After many tries to pair a new remote. I could not get it to work. So I called Amazon support. They told me that I could not use the 4K remote and to use any remote the Studio could not be pairs with any other group or Echo devices because it uses bluetooth and only one blurtooth could be paired at at a time. So to use a remote and have it also used with Fire TV was not possible. I was told even a remote from just an Echo 1st or 2nd gen would not work. Disappointing.

Bought 2 of these to pair in stereo. At full volume it has the punch I wanted to jam out and the sound is a hi fidelity sound. One thing to be aware of the default sound setting is the 3D space sound and unless specifically listening to this type of music will probably want to turn off the 3D space sound using Alexa App. At least that was my preference anyway. If you buy these don't review or judge until you've played around with 3D sound setting.
Also, like the equalizer options to adjust. Stereo pairing was easy and works great.
Have already had a couple neighbors over to listen and the 'wow' reaction is fun to see.
These speakers also have the ability to stream the hi fidelity larger file sizes that Amazon offers at an extra price. I'm currently trying out this feature. Sounds great at the regular industry standard file sizes. I think I do notice a little bit of a difference with the large hi fidelity streaming. Nice to have the option for the higher bit streams.
The bass is adequate with the 2 Echo Studios, however I'm going ahead and ordering the echo sub to get the full effect. I'm told you can do the stereo pairing of the 2 studios and also stream to the sub as well. So should be exciting when I get it setup.
I did buy these on prime day which save me some dollars.
Overall very happy with this purchase.

I am now wishing I had just bought another echo dot and went a different route for music, etc. The sound is okay, but not worth the price I paid.

Sometimes when Alexa speaks the volume suddenly drops to a level that I can't hear and then returns to correct volume when I make a new request/question.

Sometimes when I enter the room after being gone for a while, Alexa can't understand a simple request like "Den Light On" (even if I consciously pronounce the words clearly). It may take two or three tries to get the command to work. This is frustrating when you have your arms full of objects.

There are numerous questions that Alexa can't answer when I ask them. I can then speak to Google Assistant on my cell phone and get a precise answer.

Alexa system keeps losing color for bedroom light. I set it to red and then suddenly it turns back to bright white at some random point. This is very frustrating when you wake up in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom. Red doesn't fully wake me up. White wakes me up completely.

EDIT* The system loses multiple devices at once randomly. I then have to reset all of the lights causing me too much time loss.

I am exceptionally pleased with the quality of sound and the ease of installation for this product. Basically, it was a ten-minute setup, including adding it to several groups in my home. As a person who is hard of hearing, the depth of sound in these speakers makes the music I listen to much more enjoyable-- I don't need the volume to be turned up loud to hear the dots. I also appreciated that this system "sounded out" the room to adjust itself--making it appear that the entire room is filled with sound, not just the locus of the system itself.

I would buy more if I had a bigger apartment... this is a great piece of equipment.

The Echo Studio is an excellent product. It does deserve the 5 star rating, when you consider the price point and the features it provides. While the sound is excellent it wouldn't compare to a full Klipsch surround sound, but your also not paying 1/10th of the price. The bass and mids are excellent for such a small speaker, and the sound fills our living room perfectly.

The design is very aesthetically pleasing, and it blends in with our contemporary farmhouse interior design.

The microphones do a good job of picking up our voices even over the sound of music playing out of its speakers. I will definitely purchase another one of these speakers for my loft.

I'm not an audiophile but the sound on this is completely lacking. My echo plus sounds almost as good as this, if not better. And it's 4x bigger. For the size I expected to pack way more room filling sound and fore that sound to clear. If you turn it up too high it starts to crackle. Voice integration seems to be worst than all my other echo devices. It rarely picks up my voice, while my dot has no problem. Integration is ok, nothing special. Does what the others do. Hell id say get two echo plus and put them on opposite ends of the room and you'll get room filling sound, thats a 100x better than this. Gonna grab a Google max and see if thats any better.

I was very surprised by how good the Studio speaker sound. I have previously used a 7.2 setup including FOCAL speakers and McIntosh electronics. Sadly my electronics were stolen and I really can't afford to replace them. While the Echo Studio is no where near the level of that equipment, it was easily food enough that I could have happily lived with them. Unfortunately I did experiment an audio/video sync issue which could not be resolved. I see on the Echo forum where some people have this issue and many others haven't. So I can't knock the Amazon product. Results MAY vary. But I would recommend these and you DON'T need to add a subwoofer for great music reproduction.

The sound of this device far exceeds all other amazon devices I’ve heard or have thus far. I wouldn’t say it beats Sonos though. I would give it 5 stars if not for the issues around music streaming which it’s designed for. We have an echo and this studio version on a play group and this speaker stops playing all the time. There isn’t a clear consistency either. It’s extremely annoying. We primarily use Pandora as we like the fact there station selection is the most robust, but it does it with amazon music as well. For the price the sound quality is fantastic. Just wish it’s streaming capability were consistent.

I like the size and the sound of the unit. the Alexa integrations work as expected, and I use it as the primary speaker for music in a room with another echo unit. Set up as the primary, I get no contention between the two; i.e.: Echo on kitchen counter responds to voice commands for shopping lists, automation, etc where the Studio just a few feet away plays the music when asked, yet when I am closer to the studio it responds and the kitchen unit does not interfere.

The only thing I wished for was the unit had more power. Since the replaced a 13 year old JBL ipod capable room speaker (was twice the price), the volume is not as loud. Plenty to fill the room but in larger spaces it will need some help. Sound clarity at high volume remains clear, just an added note. Was worth the $149.00 on Prime day.

I just initiated my 2nd Echo Studio factory reset and figured it was time I spoke my mind about this product. I was truly excited to get one of these. I own an array of Echo products including 2 Echo shows, a 1st generation Echo and an echo dot. I live in a semi-smart home (mostly lights) and while this isn't my number one hobby, I'd like to think than I'm an enthusiast. But, Sadly, this device, or at least my particular unit, is a lemon. Most recently 'she' lost connection to the internet. I tried restarting a few times but that didn't help. This is a pretty regular occurrence, but usually a reboot fixes it. Music playback can also be problematic. This device is in my bedroom, my wife and like to enhance our intimate encounters with a little music. Well, let me tell you, nothing really sets the mood like random playback failures. A change in mid song, or long delays between tracks can be very distracting. I would be more forgiving if this where through Spodify, but I subscribed to Amazon's Music streaming service just so I could take advantage of the Atmos feature. To be clear, when it works, it's great. But more often than not, there is something buggy happening.

I've had this for about a month now and it is not impressive. The smaller dots work better when it comes to voice recognition and reliability. If I have a power outage or I reset my router for any reason, I have to spend a few HOURS trying to get the studio to work again. Yesterday I finally got it set up again after I had to turn off power for a home project. It took two attempts at resetting it before the app recognized the studio again, and then it recognized it as a SECOND studio and I couldn't get anything to work from the app to the studio.

It also doesn't appear to pick up voice commands as well as the dots and flexes. I can stand beside it and ask for something, and my dot or flex in other rooms respond while this doesn't acknowledge that I've asked something of it.

Finally, the Alexa app for Android is sloooooooow. Any actions have a long lah time between the request and the output, and the app itself is sluggish.

The sound is certainly better than the dot, etc., but it's not worth the hassle to get it working.

First and foremost if you are looking for standalone Bluetooth speaker, then the Echo Studio is a must buy. You'll be extremely happy and at 200 dollars its a home run on value and performance. Highly recommended for that aspect.

Now if you are using it as a home theater system, that is a whole another story. Let me first say I was intrigued by the Echo Studio because of the Dolby Atmos, 3D immersive sound, and just the whole complimentary features I would get being a Fire TV Cube 2nd gen user. First impressions, lets be honest, the Studio is big and ugly. But guys we can get over that, my wife hated the look of it as soon as I brought it into the house. It has an unforgiving presence, hate it or love it, kinda feel. Not a deal breaker for me but for some people its a viable reason to pass on the Studio.

Lets proceed, I am going to be honest, I tried my best to set the speaker up as a home theater system on my own going through the Alexa app. The first of many frustrations to come, I ended up having to factory reset it (deregister it) and call Amazon Alexa tech support to help me set it up. In my defense, I came from Homekit/ Siri/ Apple TV world where things are arguably a little more user friendly. The customer service/ tech support for Amazon Alexa services is outstanding. If I ever have to call them again for any issues, I feel confident that I will get my issue resolved over the phone. Alright so with the assistance of an Alexa technician guiding me through the process we were able to connect my Echo Studio to my Fire TV Cube. Thats what I wanted! It was a longer process than I wanted but I was finally there, probably took a couple hours to fiddle with it including the hold time and assistance over the phone. It is what it is, just a meh moment for me. But now I'm all set up and all is working.

Then through out the night we proceed.
Flood gates of frustration opens...

Before I take a dump on the Echo Studio, let me reiterate when sound comes out of the speaker it sounds really good. Standalone Bluetooth speaker its number one. Its without a doubt should be on anyone's radar looking for one. With the flexibility of all the music streaming services, solid mids and highs and house rattling bass, it is definitely a contender in this space. Price and value alone to me its hands down the winner.

Now lets talk about my deal breaking issues with the speaker.

Amazon advertises the Echo Studio as a theater system that supports Dolby Atmos using their latest Fire TV Cube, I told you that earlier and thats what lead me down this path. But there are issues on the software side that needs to be addressed before this even gets close to a theater system replacement.

Audio and video sync issues. Yes I know you are able to go into settings and tweak this, and so I did... various times throughout the night. It seemed like after awhile the audio and video sync would sway off and I would have to go back into the settings and tweak it again. A high frustration, but forgivable for the price. I could live with it and hope for updates to come with better syncing support. As long as nothing else was an issue I could deal with it, But I am now needing a flawless experience from here on out.

Unfortunately, flawless is not in the Studio's vocabulary.

Switching between Bluetooth music from my phone and theater system is an absolute nightmare and some how Amazon Music playing from the Fire Cube TV was thrown into the mix as well. Its like Freddy vs Jason, two nightmares into one. The studio can not handle and decide the proper channel to play the media without a little effort on the user end. Its hard to explain but juggling media playback for a theater system shouldn't have multiple sources; Bluetooth and Fire Cube TV that should be it. It seems like both devices are competing for attention, while the speaker should just be a speaker when connected to a fire cube.

Side note, "Alexa, Connect to my phone." never worked. Studio also has a hard time handling more than one Bluetooth connected device. Had to manually connect my wife's and mine's device each and every time to play music. Also a couple times I had to restart the whole set up because music wasn't playing. Restarted the Fire Cube, Studio, and phone to get music playing. My frustration is building at this point.

The final straw though was later that night while watching a show the audio without warning abruptly goes out. Video still playing but the Studio was silent. I was fed up. I wasn't going to bring something in my home that I had to babysit every night. I didn't even try to troubleshoot the issue. I did the final and last factory reset on the Studio and packaged the speaker back up to be returned.

I know I am an edge case and I am being extremely critical on some functionality , but at the end of the day, I dont want to deal with any issues. I want to set it and forget it. Give me the same sound and ugly design with a $100 higher price tag but a flawless seamless integration, I would gladly pay. I dont want to have to think when I come home, I want to flop on the couch and just watch tv. Bottom line I wanted to love the Studio, but in the end with all its perks comes unnecessary issues that I dont really need.

I DONT recommend it as a Fire TV Cube theater system set up.
I DO recommend it as a standalone bluetooth speaker.

Basically, it is a standard Echo with a large Speaker attached. But for the money that large speaker is really great. Bass that thumps but doesn't overpower the high end. It uses a variation of direct reflection technology to spread the sound through the room.

Compared to most Bluetooth speakers out there you will find you almost have to spend twice as much for the same quality.

I bought two of these. (For music you really need two speakers). With Amazon Music HD, the sound is good. But.....I still don't think it matches a traditional stereo setup with an amp/receiver powering passive speakers. What I wish Amazon would do with the HD service is offer an amp with the app integrated in. And with a DAC that can play the full 192/24 resolution for songs in that format. Power that through a pair of passive Klispch or Polk speakers and you might be in music heaven. You would get the best of both worlds: the hi fi sound of a traditional stereo with the convenience and cost effectiveness of music streaming. Come on Amazon......do it!

I have purchased eight Echos for my family and others since its debut. Being an audiophile, when I heard about the Echo Studio, I KNEW I had to have one. Dolby Atmos, 3D High Definition Music?? Yes sir!! Read great reviews and not-so-great reviews. Still ... I had to have one. And I wish I had listened to the not-so-great reviews.

The sound quality is maybe slightly better than the Echo Show. I haven't heard anything yet that sounded like "Dolby Atmos". As far as 3D?? That's a joke. I purchased a subscription to Amazon Music HD and nothing there sounds any better than normal Spotify on the first generation Echo.

Because I'm a fool, I will hold onto it for now on the slim chance that I'll buy another when they come down in price as I've read THAT'S the way to listen to it and I can imagine it'd sound slightly better with two speakers simultaneously rather than just one speaker. I dunno. Maybe I'm an idiot and a glutton for punishment. We'll see.

In the meantime I say do NOT buy this. Get the biggest Echo Show you can afford and enjoy that instead.

I bought this to replace my original Echo that I bought in pre-releaase in 2015 that has sat and worked away as a loyal soldier in the kitchen all of this time without an issue playing hundreds if not thousands of hours of music and answered uncounted numbers of questions...

WHAT AN UPGRADE! The sound of music out of this device in the poorly located position (for a music device) for the Echo in the kitchen (tucked in next to a small convection toaster) is amazing. I am listening to Ed Sheeran songs on it right now, while it sits in the kitchen, and I am in the living room 20+ feet away and it is crystal clear with actual bass.

Configuration was child's play. I unplugged the Echo, I plugged in the Studio, I started the Alexa app, clicked a few prompts, it went through some sound tests and within 3-4 minutes it was up and running playing a Classic Rewind channel for me for validation tests.

Now I have to replace the Echo in my office with one of these Studios as I regularly listen to music there as well.

Great job Amazon! :)

You would think, that spending $200 on a speaker would be a guaranteed way to listen to music but it never works. It'll play 1 song and then stop and then I can never get it to play another. I've tried Bluetooth-ing my phone to it and still, will not work. If you're not planning on listening to music, everything else works fine. But that was the whole point of me buying it.

I'm a self-professed audiophile. Dolby Atmos processing is critical to get the front tweeter working, so it's on by default for most stereo content I'm throwing thru this. Don't buy this for home theatre unless you've got a Fire TV stick. Sounds good in any large room. Overkill for small college sized single bed bedrooms.

Atmos Processing reduces the overall clarity of the music, but the increase in the soundstage is a worthwhile tradeoff, even though it dilutes the intention of the original mixes (unless you're using Amazon Music HD, with its 3D mixes.) It makes the entire wall surface (at least, above the speaker) sound like it's emanating sound, which is spectacular.

Works great as a computer speaker, I use it as my primary computer speaker. The start of sudden sounds get cut off a little, but once it realizes it's receiving line-in input, it works spectacularly. Would recommend as the best combination computer speaker / Amazon Echo device.

Stereo Separation seems dependent upon the room. You don't get the distinct directionality of stereo speakers, but rather a vague feeling of left or right along the rectangle of sound the device creates.

Voice recognition is variable. Sometimes if it hears you clearly, it doesn't need to duck the audio, which is neat. However, this is 50/50. This is the best voice recognition in any voice assistant I've ever used.

The sound is absolutely amazing. I was completely blown away by It! The only reason for not giving 5 stars is because of connectivity issues. I was under the impression that I could use the studio as a center/main channel and use two dots as side speakers for surround but apparently that's not an option at the moment, I was told the studio could only pair with another studio. Well, somehow I did get it to pair with both dots (just not simultaneously) and if they could just update the devices to work together seamlessly then it would be a truly versatile sound system. But without that capability, it's still just another Alexa, not a sound system.

As soon as I plugged it in, it registered itself and did the whole setup on its own. I never had to open the app or anything.

At first listen I was very disappointed in the sound quality. It did not sound any better than the Echo Show it replaced. It sounded like music was coming from a canister or drum. Then I turned off Stereo Spatial Emhancement in Alexa App settings and maxed out the equalizer. After a few minutes it started to sound great! Bass was deep and tight, mids and trebble were clear! I read in another review online and they described it best: this speaker "has no chill." Hard to deacribe. You gotta hear it for yourself.

ENJOYING IT TREMENDOUSLY AS A MUSIC CENTER HAT MAKES IT EASY TO PLAY WHATEVER MY FAMILY WANTS TO HEAR , WITH MINIMUM EFFORT , SINCE ALEXA DOES ALL THE SEEKING AND SEARCHING FOR ME.
FOR SOME REASON ALEXA HAS A VERY DIFFICULT TIME FINDING THE MUSIC OF MY FAVORITE PIANO PLAYER , [ WADZIU ] WALTER VALENTINO LIBERACE , SINCE NO MATTER WHAT I CALL HIM , OR HOW I CALL HIM , OR HOW I PRONOUNCE HIS NAME , IT TAKE ME A LEAST TEN TRIES TO FINALLY MANAGE TO GET ALEXA TO LOCATE HIM !
AND I TRY: LIBERACE , WALTER LIBERACE , WADZIU LIBERACE , LIBERACE WALTER , LIBERACE WADZIU , LIBERACE , ETC. AND IT REQUIRES LOT OF TRIES TO FINALLY GET ALEXA TO UNDERSTAND MY INSTRUCTIONS.
BUT WHEN IT FINALLY DOES , I CAN SPEND ALL DAY LISTENING TO HIS WONDERFUL MUSIC IN HIGH DEFINITION.
WHEN USING TWO ECHO STUDIOS AS A STEREO PAIR IT IS ABSOLUTELY ESSENTIAL TO CHOOSE ONLY ONE OF THE TWO SPEAKERS TO RECEIVE THE INSTRUCTIONS , AND KEEP THE OTHER MIKE AT THE RED DISABLED POSITION , OTHERWISE YOU WILL GET CONFLICTING INSTRUCTIONS AND CONFUSED RESULTS !

This sounds just as good if not better, and costs just 200 bucks. Worth it for big sound. + Alexa built in, I'm sold. I've hooked it up to my xbox via a mini-toslink to toslink cable I bought on amazon for 6 bucks to play racing games as well and it sounds great.

The Studio is great as a stand alone Alexa speaker, but isn’t very good paired with a FireTV. You’ll constantly be annoyed by the lag between picture and sound. The sound lag on YouTube and Hulu make them completely unusable. If you don’t mind hearing the words 2-3 seconds after seeing lips move, this is the speaker for you.

Huge headache. It’s disappointing because when it works it sounds great. Have it paired with my 4K fire stick for the home theater experience. The problem is it won’t connect for at least 5 to 10 minutes after turning on the tv. I have tried every option to try to get this issue resolved. I don’t have this issue when I go through a mini toslink but I have to unpair it from my fire stick for echo studio to do so. If paired it will only speak to the fire stick through WiFi regardless if you plug in an optical cable. But this defeats the whole purpose of my echo home theater dreams, might as well get a sound bar. I have reached out to customer support but as sweet as they were they really had no clue how to help me. I was on the phone with them for over an hour for them to only wish me luck and hope my issue is resolved. This is already the replacement for the first studio that I got which kept freezing and get stuck in a loop. I also bought it new but the replacement I got was clearly opened before. It was delivered in its own package, taped all over with the delivery address slapped on the side. It’s been a huge headache, which is a shame because when it works I love it.

I love the sound on the Echo Studio, though not comfortable at high volumes. Sound level 3 or 4 quite enjoyable. The voice recognition has issues compared to my Echo Dot device. Background noise from my TV causes far more “I did not understand/try again later” responses than with the Echo Dot. It is also inconsistent on sound levels for music, alarms, reminders and notifications, seemingly randomly announcing things at abnormally loud volume s levels. I would not pay full price for this unit - I got mine for 25% off on a Best Buy Amazon Devices sale. I cannot recommend as much as I should due to the Alexa voice recognition issues.

Just a little background on my taste. I’m pretty deep in both amazon and apple products for many years now. And I’m a bit of an audiophile. I don’t have speakers like these in my house but I wanted to set up a hub to control lights etc. in my apartment so two birds is what I thought. Especially since I don’t want to have a full blown sound system in my small apartment. I’ve had the older generation Echo dot and it sounded terrible. I ordered this Studio when it first came to market expecting an upgrade but was pretty disappointed. It’s rather flat sounding in my opinion hence the mediocre review. I really should have returned it.

In any event, I am giving away my old Dot after receiving the new generation Echo yesterday. At a hundred bucks it sounds better than the Studio. So now I have the new Echo in my bedroom and Studio in living room. Both handle voice commands well. But I’d recommend the new Echo over the Studio. The sound is open and airy. Highs are crisp and the bass is punchy in a smaller footprint. The sound on the Studio is just blah. Everything else works fine so 3 stars.

The speaker is as expected.
I had to move it around a bit an re-calibrate it a few times.
If you are in the same boat, hold down the action button, it will go into setup mode, showing an orange ring.
DON'T let go of the button and keep holding it down beyond this for a wee bit more.
It will then kick of the whole process of starting up as it did the first time and do the wall bouncing thingy.

Anyways, my gripe is not the speaker but the bulb that came packaged with the purchase.
I already got a Philips hue bulb in a previous Echo purchase and that works fine. No need for a Philips hue hub, just the built in zigbee hub that the Echo plus (which I have) or this Echo Studio has.

However, this bulb does require a Philips hue hub.
What numb nuts is not paying attention to this in Amazon when they put these items for sale as a package?
Why not the Philips hue bulb that works with a zigbee hub that the Echo you are purchasing has built into it?

Other than that, the speaker works as expected. I do prefer to turn off the 'Stereo Spatial Enhancement' under the audio settings for the Echo Studio in the Alexa app under 'Audio settings'.

I was actually looking for ways to improve the sound on my TV and saw a promo of the Studio. I went ahead and order one and got it quickly, set it up in my master and played around with it. I have Amazon Music, played some of their 3D demo music and was sold on Rocket Man. Immediately upgraded to Prime 3D Music. Connected it to the TV and pulled up Blade Runner 2049, Thor Dark World and Avengers EndGame and on a single Studio was wowed by the sound filling my master. So withing days, I order a second Studio and upon arrival, moved both into our family room and now have it fully integrated with our large TV. That room has 26 foot ceilings and opens to several other rooms but the sound reached everywhere. It also sets up with left and right speakers and you can hear some really crazy subtle noises that I don't even remember hearing in the theater. I now stream every app I can through the Fire Stick (get with the program on HBO Max, Amazon!!!)

As for just music, the bass can be a bit overwhelming and there is not a lot of control in the equalizer on the Alexa app. I don't claim to be an audiophile but I own thousands of songs via iTunes and know good v great sound quality. Amazon is better than good and on most songs, especially those that are in 3D, the quality is pretty fantastic. But I also really like heavy metal and given drums and bass dominance in bands like Tool, the really deep tones can be a little overwhelming. But Tool also has tracks in 3D and the nuances that sneak through the heavy bass are really interesting. On more pop or pop rock music, it's not as prevalent and really quite enjoyable. We'll see if I can survive the holiday season streaming my wife's Christmas music.

If you subscribe to Amazon Music, I recommend pairing this with a TV whether you intend to use it for a sound system or not. With Fire TV, the remote syncs to the Studio and controls TV and speakers. It makes access to the music catalog and all of their HD and Ultra HD quality music fairly simple. There could be some improvements like better access to genres and then sub sections within but overall a decent way to get artists or albums to play. They also have quite a few playlists pre-created, some of which are pretty good.

Overall, for $400 to get 2 Studio's and a couple more Hue lights, I can't think of a better way to get a serious TV sound improvement (that really will rattle the rafters) and a much better than good smart speaker.

It's important to say that my Echo-Studio was a gift. I did not seek out and purchase this item for myself. The giver knew my taste for classical music and for this it was a well-chosen gift. There are so many reviews of the Echo Studio that I can only say this device does what it claims to do. Initially, I did not like the non-directional sound, but the longer I've used it, the more I see the benefit of the room-filling sound, especially when one needs to get up and move around. The sound is uniform at almost any point in the room. The Studio is sturdy and heavy, which means no rattles or buzzing when playing music at a higher volume level.

Is the sound as good as advertised? Frankly, it *is* good, though not as good as my old Bose Mini which has superb clarity and a wide stereo sound stage. Then the Bose does not have the connectivity and other features of the Echo Studio. I tried Amazon 3D audio and was only mildly impressed. It wasn't so superior as to induce me to subscribe.

Then, it must be said that the Echo Studio, like all Amazon devices, is at some level a conduit for enticing one to buy more from Amazon. Here it's more subtle, but once Alexa learns the owner's voice, it can be used to purchase items from Amazon by verbal command. I wave no red flag. I've been an Amazon customer for over two decades with no desire to end that relationship.

The only negative I have experienced so far was a verbal notification from Amazon. Alexa asked me to review the Echo Studio! I answered with an emphatic NO! Please, Amazon, take note! We get spam by email, spam by text, and if spam starts to come by Alexa on my devices, I will shut them down.

Alexa is a primary feature of the Echo Studio, I must say that it can be difficult to get her to fetch the music one wants. If you seek Justin Bieber or Katy Perry, no problem. As a subscriber to Amazon Music Unlimited, I ought to have access to millions of 'songs'. When I asked to hear Mozart's opera The Marriage of Figaro, I got the overture to the Barber of Seville by Rossini. Granted, Figaro is the protagonist in both works, but multiple tries to play the correct music caused Alexa to shut down! I later searched for the music I wanted on the Amazon Music app on my mobile and there were multiple versions of the opera to enjoy. Alexa may be handy but she is no deus ex machina.

This is my only complaint, and it's a big one, but before I start I have to say the good first.
1. 3D MUSIC - Ultra HD- is real (it is by Amazon amazon music HD only) Amazon unlimited and amazon unlimited HD are NOT the same, you have to add the HD PACK.

2. DOBLY ATMOS IS INCREDIBLE

3. the sound is incredible

the bad things

Now, dobly atmos only works WITH FIRETICK 4K AND ONLY IN AMAZON PRIME VIDEO, it does not work with Netlix, APPLE TV, DISNEY + and it doesn't matter if you are using the apps in the FIRESTICK 4k unfortunately you will never experience DOBLY ATMOS, to finish Destroying this incredible device for what was created, if I found only 3 movies or series on DOBLY ATMOS in Amazon Prime, is a lot. Almost all of his films are UHD DOBLY DIGITA PLUS, which are not Dobly atmos.

2. 3D music is fine but very limited almost unstable

We have a number of Echo devices and were excited to add the Studio in our main living area and also use it to watch movies.

The audio is great compared to all other Echo devices.

The home theater feature is technically very exciting and connects seamlessly with the fire TV, too bad that sometimes audio skips and with some apps the audio is a few milliseconds delayed. The audio skipping made the feature unusable for movies. When you have this feature on if you play music say from Spotify, that also turns your TV on and plays Spotify from your fire TV. This is also unreliable as sometimes the fire tv doesn’t actually turn on OR it turns on but it doesn’t open the app.

We even went to buy an optical cable and this also has two different issues a) you can only change the volume with your voice and b) audio is ALSO unreliable is it sometimes suddenly completely mutes and you have to unplug the cable and when you turn te TV or program off you get some sort of residual audio.

Overall a disappointment that I hope a software update will fix.

Save you money. It's not worth all these 5 stars you see here. The people who are raving about this speaker must have been using their laptop speakers for music before this. I just honestly don't get all of these reviews. The equalizer in the app to change the sound is worthless with very basic adjustments. I know since I spent a lot of time trying to get this speaker to sound decent. The vocal's are muted at the expense of the bass and you can't pull them to the front very well, vocals as you are use to hearing them on the radio or CD or Album are not present. And, I subscribed to Amazon's HD music trial to see if that would make the difference and it just didn't. I have a UE Boom speaker I've been very satisfied with but thought I'd try this after reading all the reviews and it was on sale. Honestly, now that I have the HD trial stream the UE even sounds better than before and you can get this regularly for under $100.00. So many other things I could say here but really if you are going to buy this for enjoyable music reproduction this isn't it.

Bought two and paired them as stereo speakers in the living room. They replace a 15-year old Bose large CD-player boom box that died of control malfunctions. I had hoped this new technology would equal or surpass the Bose. It doesn't even come close, which I suppose I should have expected considering that the Bose box cost 6 times as much and has a lot more technology in it than these. If this is Amazon's attempt at decent sound, they have quite a way to go. The mid-range sound on these is very muddy. This is not high- fidelity quality. It's OK for what it is, and the stereo arrangement is sufferable. Hooking up just one, however, was not adequate for my background "easy listening" purposes. I was on the edge of sending them back, but, I love being able to bounce all around the history of music just by asking Alexa to play this or play that, or asking WHat song is this, or Who is playing this song. That part, I love. But of course you have to pay around 150 a year or so for Amazon music access.

The sound quality of this device is the real deal! For a stand alone speaker it sounds beautiful with rich mid-low to even a decent treble! It has okay performance with the low ranges but it certainly would benefit greatly from the echo sub pairing.

The 3D audio is a really fun gimmick though it will never truly replace a true surround sound system because everyone's house/ room is going to be different and there are also so few options to really take advantage of the 3D audio anyways.

The offline voice recognition and zigbee hub is absolutely great! I love being able to control my lights almost instantly without it having to access an online database.

The major drawback that I have is I really wanted to connect my echo studio to my firestick 4k to take advantage of the Dolby Atmos Plus audio of both devices! This unfortunately cannot happen because the studio cannot handle streaming of video and streaming the audio at the same time. (yes, my internet is fine. everyother device in my house can handle streaming 4k) I tried everything and talked to representatives for over 6 cumulative hours trying to diagnose this. It handles streaming amazon music and streaming the album to the tv just fine, but video is where it falls apart. Amazon sent me a replacement device but it still was dropping audio literally every second. Like the packet for the other half of the audio was dropped in communications and so it clips in and out (But not stereoscopically so). This is a huge bummer for me because I really got this device to have a decent sounding wireless speaker to go with the TV but at this point I just wish I could hardwire the Studio to the Firestick 4k and still retain the Dolby Atmos Plus quality (Which you can't in a hardwire from the TV to the Studio, it just treats it like any other speaker).

Overall, this speaker is great as a super Alexa device! If you're looking for a huge but excellent sounding Echo device for a room in your house and are not wanting to use it for streaming movie audio, this speaker is amazing! If you're hoping to make use of the Dolby Atmos Plus for your FireTV though, I'd say to save your money and look elsewhere.

I don't know how you can beat the sound of a stereo pair of Echo Studio's for the money. I ordered 2 and have mine set up as a stereo pair. Will they fill up a large room at concert volume? No but for a smaller room/apartment or for a whole house or secondary system they are amazing. I don't have them paired with a Fire TV so can't speak to that but my wife and I listen to them by streaming Amazon Music HD and I really do hear things in songs particularly on the high end I've never heard before. They are so good you tell the difference between an HD stream and an MP3 service. I don't consider myself a true audiophile but I do spend a lot of money on 2 channel and home theatre gear and I'm very impressed with the sound of these speakers. I had them set up in under 10 minutes. The Echo Sub is sold out and not available at the time of this review but I have pre-ordered it and I'm really looking forward to adding it to the speaker group.

Note to Amazon: You have a great product here. I would suggest making a larger scale version of these - say 1.5 or 2 times the size for people who want to fill up a bigger space. I'd gladly pay more for something like that.

Shockingly good sound from such a relatively small device. Setup is mostly easy. Had some issues setting up home entertainment system mode with fire stick. It did not work independently and respond to Alexa requests. Had to remove, reinitialize etc and then it worked. Was frustrating. I have two of these in different rooms and one was effortless the other a pain.
Got over it quickly when I put on a movie and it filled the room with 3D-ish sound and good low end. I’m sure if I put 2 together with a sub it would be killer.
I use the fire stick for everything so it isn’t as limiting as I thought it would be.
I have a DVD player (rarely use) and Nintendo switch and use the tv sound. Not enough of a deal breaker to make me get a big clunky sound bar. Kids don’t care that switch sound comes from tv.
Wish list item would be ability to re-calibrate room sensing thing without reinstalling. I moved it around a bit and it doesn’t feel like it automatically fixed the positioning.

I bought the Echo Studio for two reasons. 1) good sound 2) Echo Plus SmartHome zigbee hub

The sound is great but the SmartHome features are half baked.

It supports many Zigbee bulbs and motion sensors, however the user interface (alexa app and voice control) does not support switchs or any tactile controls. For example Ikea sells a Zigbee Bulb and wireless dimmer switch kit. Both the dimmer control and the bulb can be paired with echo, but the user interface only recognizes the bulb. Amazon has not built progamatic support for taktile controls.

Also there is no IF THEN OR logic available for SmartHome routines. There is time controls but that is limited.

I bought a Linkind Brand Motion Sensor and use it to trigger a routine. If I enter the kitchen anytime between 6:00 am and 7:30 am it plays the morning news and turns on a light. This is great because the routine is time and motion based.

When the echo products went on a limited time sale, I purchased the Studio to replace my Echo 2nd gen. The setup was effortless as it recognized my network and added itself via the app. To my disappointment, I immediately realized that the mid and upper range was directional. The speaker was in a central location on top of a kitchen counter almost in the middle of a large open space (kitchen, den, and dining areas). When I walked around the unit the sound was not uniform. For a few hours, I contemplated returning it, then I moved the studio to a corner of my 11" x 29" enclosed lanai with the unit supported about a foot off of the floor. What a difference! Now I love it! The bass is so much deeper than the Echo 3rd gen and voices sound more lifelike. Where you place this unit matters. When you find the right spot, the sound quality is wonderful. I gave the studio 4 stars because I could not use it in the location that I purchased it for. For that spot, I bought an Echo 3rd generation.

We wanted to like this BUT we had so much difficulty connecting especially when you have multiple devices. We also got the Echo Sub which only worked when my husbands phone was connected to it but for the life of me I could not get the sub to work when connected to my phone. This device only seemed to work well with Amazon Music services. I could not get this to work with Apple Music at all or any other services. It got so frustrating we decided to return it. We are pretty technically savy and this was the most annoying products to use compared to other wireless Bluetooth players. Lots of work still needs to be done to improve the technology.

Bought to use in Florida room. When listening to music, there isn't a huge difference between listening to my original Echo device. Would probably sound better if paired with another, but then for the price of two, might as well buy a Bose.

Everything about the Echo Studio is great except that it can't wake me up in the morning to near perfect sound. I have an additional Echo and Echo Sub which together combine for fantastic, near perfect stereo/3D music. But...the alarm (wake up) function will only allow the music to come from the Echo Studio. Granted, I can wake up to "good" sound from just the Studio alone. The drawback here is that I have two different equalizer preferences; one for just the Studio and one for the entire system so this solution does not meet my idea of perfection since only one equalizer setting can be stored at a time. I have since moved my Studio and Sub to another room and have fantastic sound there and have reverted to using my Echo Show 10" as my alarm clock pending a hopeful Amazon upgrade.

An additional note is that the Echo Studio sounds great by itself but sounds MUCH better when paired with an Echo Sub.

Over all this speaker is amazing. I have a Sonos before this and wanted something with more Alexa features as well as well rounded sound. None of the other Amazon speakers were as good as Sonos in audio quality. I played with a demo of this in Best Buy before I pre-ordered this. And I have no regrets. My ONLY problem is I prefer Apple Music and she doesn’t play the best all the time with it. Sometimes I’ll be randomly disconnected and have sign in again. The speaker itself is incredible.

I bought this smart speaker as prime day deal, In my mind I had more expectations that are not reached up to the mark that's the only reason I'm giving 4 stars . Actually I bought this speaker for my projector and expected good home theater sound but its not as expected but when we see it as induvial smart speaker then its good.
For my projector I used Amazon fire stick and amazon speaker. As "Smart" devices FireStick should integrate(connect) with speaker but that is lagging. Thats the Alexa integration given 4 stars.
Coming to sound quality. No doubt sound quality is very good but at this price range we should have more volume of sound. I'm using 8 or 9 pts of sound out of10 pts to enjoy the music.. Actually by using 6 or 7 points volume we should get expected volume level.
Overall product is good if it is around 120 to 130 price range if more than that... better find alternative if you have concern particularly about volume levels.

This is a well built and great sounding speaker for the cost. Amazon is really competing with the big brands with this one. Still evaluating the 3D music but Amazon Ultra HD music sounds fantastic on this speaker. Plenty loud and clear. Can't go wrong with this speaker.

I had a pair of Bose speakers in my bedroom, voices were always difficult to decipher at the lower volume levels needed in the bedroom to keep peace with my wife. After hearing several speakers in the $200-$400 range I decided on the Echo, brought it home, hooked it up (easy peasy). I'm amazed at the clarity of the voices coming from this speaker even at the lowest levels. Exactly what I needed. I paid $169 for this and it came with a free light bulb, what else could I ask for?
Update! This speaker sits next to my right ear. I'm watching football last night and I hear cheering from the left side of the room!! Thinking I'm hearing things I muted the speaker, sure enough, voices were coming from the right but the sound was bouncing off the walls, all the while at a low volume level, this is a good-sized Master bedroom. The separation is almost as good as the 10K system in my living room. Love this speaker!!

The best speak system that I've ever owned! The pairing in Home Theater node via Amazon Fire Cube Gen1 was sketchy at first but it seemed to have sorted itself out. I can hear things in old movies and shows that I have never heard before! Often, while watching a show, one of the cats will think they heard something in the house and immediately respond but it's only the speakers. That's house realistic they sound!!

These have excellent bass. The sound quality and richness is better than anything I have ever owned, hands down.

Complaints? I don't know. I wish I could ask it to place music without flipping on the TV. It's cool to see the lyrics though.

The Echo Studio has incredible microphones. They are better than any Echo device. I could be in another room and they hear me better than the Echo that's in the room where I'm at.

Not cheap but worth every penny. Honestly? Now I want more for the bedroom.

I ordered this during Amazon Deal Days so I got it for a decent price. I think if I would have paid the full price I would have been more disappointed. It is a large speaker with a small footprint. The sound is good and they made sure to dial back the volume level a bit so it does not distort at full volume. Set up is easy as could be and takes only a few minutes to get set up and running. Voice recognition is good is a lot better than the smaller speakers. It is not my go-to speaker when I want to Rock but as a daily driver for when I want to just listen to a podcast or stream music for background music.

The first official Echo device to feature really great sound. I’ve been looking so long for an Alexa-integrated high-quality speaker, since the Echo and Dot don’t quite achieve that for me, and the fantastic Dolby tech integrated into the speaker pulled me towards the Studio (plus, unlike non-Amazon devices, this being an Echo device means it’s backed by Amazon’s excellent support team. If you’re looking for a speaker with great sound and worth the price, I’d highly recommend this one.

Pros:
- Sounds excellent! Incredibly good sound! Tight bass, excellent clarity good mdis, and great highs. I am a picky sound person and this really sounds good! So good!!!!

- Aesthetics - Looks good! I like the space underneath it. It looks cool and modern!

- Buttons are high quality

Cons:
- I have the first generation echo and I think the mic pics up my voice better for waking up on the first generation echo

- I wish the notification light was not recessed and brighter. This sits on my breakfast bar and you can not really see when the unit is activated. On my first gen echo, the light was clearly visible.

- I miss the physical round knob for volume that was on the first gen echo. It is so much easier to adjust volume on the first gen echo with the round knob versus the buttons on the echo.

Overall, I am really happy with this purchase. The sound is just incredible! I am going to buy a second unit for my bedroom. Amazon really knows how to make a good product! Way better than the Google Home products that I have.

I started with an Echo Dot (3rd Gen) and an Echo Input (connected to my stereo receiver). I have since added 2 more Echo Dots, an Echo Flex with Motion Sensor, and now the Echo Studio. The Echo Studio was very easy to setup, looks beautiful, and fills our living room with nice sound. My one complaint is the microphone doesn't seem to hear commands very well. Our Echo Dot upstairs will often pickup commands said downstairs, but the Echo Studio seems to have trouble hearing commands said in the same room. The only other feature I wish it had was Apple Airplay 2.

I created a speaker group with the Studio and Echo Input so that I can play music "downstairs" in multiple rooms. I also created a routine that will turn off all music on all Echo devices, cause sometimes Alexa just gets confused and starts playing out of the wrong device. So far I have found it very easy to use and very flexible.

The good: The sound is good, not great, even when paired in stereo mode with another Echo Studio and an Echo Sub. I also think they look pretty cool, although my wife disagrees.

The bad: The price is much too high for what you get. The sound quality is good, but for $200 I expect something that sounds much better, cleaner, and with more depth. The "Alexa" smart assistant feature is terrible. It can barely hear me and often requires me to repeat a command 3 or so times (which is much worse than even my original (beta) Echo v1. These things are huge (about the size of a volleyball) and are difficult to place around the home, especially when paired with another Echo Studio and an Echo Sub. I really expected much better, richer sound quality for the price. Considering what you can get for the cost of two Echo Studios and an Echo Sub in the traditional speaker market, I'm pretty disappointed with the sound quality, and I'm not even an Audiophile. Finally, it doesn't look like you can use these as TV speakers unless you have one of the newer Amazon Fire TV devices. I expected these to play sound for my TV, including my Roku, PS4, and other video devices, even if that was limited to stereo quality sound, but these lack that capability apparently.

The Echo Plus is a fairly "bass" heavy speaker. Like lots of its competitors, they emphasize bass, so you think you're getting great sound from a small speaker. The Studio certainly has an impressive woofer, but it delivers a much more even range across the spectrum of the music being played. So that should be great, right? Well, that depends on what you're playing. If you ask Alexa to play "best of 3D Music" (which Amazon will keep reminding you to do) - OMG - it's fantastic. But then check on the price of a subscription to 3D Music, and not so fantastic. Regular music through Amazon Music Unlimited is a lot flatter. But then I do a bluetooth to my phone and play from my YouTube Music Premium account, and it sound great. So I can't help but wonder why Amazon Music sounds worse than that. It seems to be a push for you to get the 3D Music subscription. That's why I give 4 stars. Otherwise it works well as an Alexa device and the mics are very sensitive.

By the way Amazon - time for some new "wake word" options. You want us to load up on devices that end up being close to one another, and yet you have 4 wake words, and 2 of those are not easy to say.

i’m very picky about audio and this just isn’t doing it for me. MAYBE if it was in a perfectly square room it might sound better? i’m not a fan of the “stereo spatial enhancement”, you lose things in the music. with that enhancement turned off it still doesn’t sound that great, it’s very mid heavy. you really only get good rich bass on songs that are already bass heavy otherwise you don’t get much at all. The songs that are mastered in 3-D don’t impress me at all. I would DEFINITELY purchase two third gen Echo’s and the sub over this. i’ll just Bluetooth the audio from my echo show to my sound bar and save the $200.

If you have weak wi fi signal Alexa will shut down and not restart until you give verbal instructions. So unless you have a very strong wi fi signal do not not bother with this. I had it for a week and it constantly shut down when wi fi signal wavered and will not resume unless you give verbal instructions to restart. No good in an area like mine where ATT signal is weak. Am returning the Alexa studio. cannot understand why a restart program is not a crucial part of this device when wi fi signal is weak or lost.

I bought the Echo Studio in early April along with a FireTV Cube so that I could have easy voice control over my TV, and good quality sound without spending an arm and leg on the sound quality (like with Bose, Sonos, or other highly rated soundbars with Alexa integrated). Setup was very easy as with other Echo products. But setup and pairing with the FireTV cube was a bit more complex and confusing - took a good 5 minutes. The Studio speaker is not listed in the FireTV soundbar options, only a generic Amazon soundbar. So I was concerned whether everything would work correctly. For the first few days, everything worked beautifully, just as I had expected.

After using it for a few days with the FireTV, Cube we noticed that the audio would just cut out for a couple seconds in the middle of someone saying something on a show. Had to rewind so you could understand what was going on. It didn't seem to matter whether the show was on HBO Now, Netflix, or Amazon Prime. Very annoying. The frequency and amount of time the sound would cut out got worse the longer we used the speaker. To solve the problem, I had to reset the speaker and re-pair it with the Cube - not something you want to deal with in the middle of a show.

I put up with this for another week or so, as it seemed to work OK for several days at time. Then when I was trying to reset/re-pair with the Cube, the speaker would say "Sorry, the internet is not available right now". That wasn't true because the Cube was connected over the same Wi-Fi router in the same room. For some reason, it would not recognize my Wi-Fi router. The only way to fix this was to unplug the speaker and start all over again. This happened a couple more times so I gave up and decided to return the speaker. FireTV Cube works great, but not with the Studio speaker. I'm going to break down and spend the extra cash on a Sonos soundbar.

It's bigger than I thought. The bass and treble, well it hits high highs and low lows, but the mid range is rather muddy. I imagine they can fix that with software after feedback encourages them. 3D sound is cool, but there is little content at this juncture. Only had it a day and my neighbors know I have it.
It is by far the best sound device in the Echo series.
I initially gave this 5 stars. Came back to give it 4 stars then while writing the part of the review below I changed it to three stars.
After using it a bit the sound levels are so inconsistent that the unit requires constant attention. Played songs by Maurice Ravel. It started with Bolero. I didn't hear anything until finally I heard the faint whispers of the song. So I said next song. Impressions de France came up loud and clear.
This happened with multiple other songs. One song played, I adjusted the volume. The next song came on either a great deal louder or lower. This has happened several times.
Update 10/28/2020
Changed my review to 2 stars. My Echo dot in the bathroom, on the other side of the apartment understands me. But neither Echo Studio understands me that well. It is so inconsistent as a speaker system and voice control. Frustrating...

Cannot stereo pair with any older devices, completely useless for stereo sound. There is a mono device. No amount of technology in the Studio is going to overcome its poor mono sound compared to stereo. Amazon, your speaker engineers need to have their ears checked and their degrees questioned. Returning device for some other schmuck to buy refurbished.

I bought 2 of these for the best sound and for the Atmos effects. Sound quality is really good, Atmos effect, so so. You can't be sitting anymore than 6 or 7 feet away from the speakers to get the full benefit of the Atmos effect. Bass is good and dialogue is good as well. I bought a fire TV cube in order to pair them as a home theater setup.

What's annoying is that when you sit down to watch something, the sound doesn't always come up. You have to keep switching the program on and off until the sound finally comes through. Also, you can be watching a program and either 1 or both speakers will cut out for no reason at all (extremely annoying). It got so bad I finally replaced them with a sound bar with wireless subwoofer and rear speakers. A bit costly but MUCH better than having the sound turn off for no reason at all.

I'd say this is a great concept but not really ready for prime time yet. I would have to say out of all the Echo products I've purchased, these were a big disappointment.

This is no louder or better than my echo plus. The first day I had problems with the sound going up and down. I’ve got six echo dots, 2 echo 2nd gen, 3 echo 3rd gen, 1 echo plus, a few echo inputs and an echo show in every room. I love all of them except this one. It is a huge disappointment.

Update. A week or so after my review Amazon called and was able to walk me threw something that helped the volume problem.

Tonight I moved the Studio to my Den and set up a Home Theater with my Fire TV 4K. OK, what a difference in the sound. I previously had an old Bose 5 speaker and bass home theater set up to my tv. There is no comparison to the sound I am getting with the Echo Studio. I can feel the bass and the sound is so clear. No more need for close captioning to read what didn’t come through clear enough on the Bose. I am so impressed. I will for sure be getting another Echo Studio to pair with it. Can’t imagine what that will sound like.

Okay, so where do i begin?

If you like jazz, great speaker. Play some John Coltrane and it wafts through the speakers and tickles your ears. Diana Washington's September in the Rain is a great song on Amazon Music HD to test it.

If you like rock, well you will be slightly disappointed. i found that bass was ok, but midrange was lacking on many songs. That Smell by Lynyrd Skynyd is plain and faceless. Rolling Stones songs were meh.

Modern pop rock is ok, and that doesn't take a lot to reproduce.

Overall, I give it a 3 of 5. Alexa misses hearing me 1/3 or the time or miscommunicates when it does. Not so with my Alexa Dot, which is spot on everytime.

This is kinda like the story of the 3 bears, no one will be happy but can you live with the bed you laid in, perhaps, but for the price? Maybe not. Its not a Sonos killer even though they try to be, or even a HEOS comparison. For the price, perhaps if you put up with its warts...

You guys..... help me!

I have a few echos throughout the house, from the plus to the show and the latest one is the Echo Studio. I’ve had the worst time with music streaming. I’ve upgraded to all the premium memberships. HD, family plan, unlimited we’re purchased because echos weren’t playing music in different rooms with the membership I had before. So I upgrade to the best so I can enjoy and it’s been so glitchy and totally not HD sounding. I’ve compared the same songs on amazon and Apple Music and Apple Music has the incredible clarity and rich defined sounds on several songs. Apple Music doesn’t even advertise “ultra hd” or whatever and their music is SOOOO much better.

Unfortunately I’ve purchased so many echoes and smart home items that I will not return them all like I did last year. This time around I’m having a horrible problem where my echoes play explicit songs bleeped! What actual f word????? AMAZON, really???? I have called tech support several times and they’ve guided to turn off the filter (not like I hadn’t done that a million times before) such a turn off, amazon! We pay extra for HD and sounds sub par, tired in several speakers and Apple Music sounds way better. And another thing is the false advertising. I’ve had several songs clearly indicating explicit and then the words are bleeped. I can’t 😔

Simply put, not worth the price.

The speaker lacks consistent volume output. A device this expensive should have an internal volume stabilizer so all music plays at the actual volume you select.

As for the sound, look it's only going to be as good as what it receives and if you're going to be listening to music from the Amazon music playlist, you will really be disappointed. Little care goes into actually matching the mood or category you select and even then this speaker lacks clarity and definition, let alone adequate bass without pushing it.

True, the Studio has its own HUB and that's a plus, but, so too, does the Echo.

All in all. It's an average sound and does not give good base unless played at a level greater than, I suspect, most people care to listen to.

Spend $200 if you feel the need, as I did. I only hope you're not as disappointed as I am.

If you have Alexa devices for home automation this is a really nice addition if you care about how your music and/or home theater sounds. It's a Dolby Atmos audio system if you have a Fire TV, which is really nice. It sounds better than sound bars, but not quite as good as a Dolby Atmos home theater system with components, unless you pair 2 of the Studios with an Echo Sub. That's where the really good stuff happens. But, for just a single unit, it pumps out some really nice sound with plenty of bass, but not overpowering or muddy. It sounds very tight and accurate. Compared to the Apple Homepod, it's not quite as accurate and clear, but it's close, and the Studio gets quite a bit louder. The Studio also has a built-in hub for Hue lights and other devices. At normal price, it's a solid purchase for home automation and audio. If you can catch the Studio on sale, it's very easy to recommend.

The sound quality of this unit is great. Unfortunately, how I use it the most is listening to music, and it often fails at that. Sometimes, when I tell Alexa to "play Spotify", nothing happens. When I open Spotify on my computer, it shows that it is connected to the unit. When I press Play, nothing happens. The song does not play. After restarting Spotify on my computer, it often resets, and everything works. Sometimes it doesn't. When it doesn't, I have to unplug the Echo Studio to restart it.

I also have an Echo Dot, and there has never been any problems getting Spotify to play on it.

For the price of this unit, I would expect it to work better.

We went straight from an antiquated Dot - which was definitely showing its age and becoming very "laggy" to the Echo Studio. Whereas you could never really get the Dot to play loud enough, you'll find yourself saying "Alexa, turn down the volume" more than you'd expect (and that's a good thing). With shockingly good bass, and the ability to broadcast sound far beyond its immediate vicinity, the Echo Studio is a massive step forward and essentially a replacement for all but higher end home sound systems. We all unanimously agree; worth every penny.

The studio is disconnecting sound intermittently from fire Tv 4k when set-up as a home theater - all support is offering is to exchange the studio - the internet is full of this problem and no solution have been found to exchange the studio is not solving the problem.

Reading the reviews for Echo studio and the specs - It states on the spec page that it is 330 watts. This is definitely NOT the case. You need to take this specification off of the spec [age. Also, I do not know if it is a Studio issue or a Amazon issue, but I tried to have it play songs by artist Joe Friedman...Well it played 2 songs by Joe Friedman and then it started playing some random opera song. I asked Alexa what it was playing and it said that "No music was being played". It never did this until I got this device. So there is some issue that is keeping me from using this device as it should work. It does process faster than the smaller Alexa devices. If I had to do this over, I would probably wait until they come out with the 2nd generation and see if it is any better.

With the highly rated reviews I was really expecting this to be special, but after listening to it for an hour and requesting HD music, all I can say is Meh....

It's nicer than an Echo or Echo dot, but not an Echo dot plugged into my TV's 7.2 $400 sound system.

One review said it filled the room with sound. Must be a small apartment dweller.

It's akin to a nice radio, but a long ways away from a good stereo.

Would not recommend and will return.

The included Alexia Phillips light bulb works great and is a keeper though.....
About to purchase another one and two wireless subwoofers, this echo studio ain't nothing but the truth and I'm a Bose owner of several types (companion 2 and accoustimass 7).

I wanted this to use as a soundbar for my TV when watching and for an Echo when I am busy and want to listen, and it does both perfectly. I plugged in the optic cord and it works better than I expected to fill the room and clear up the TV audio, and I just say "alexa, mute" when I get or make a phonecall, then "Alexa, unmute" when I'm done - don't even have to reach for the remote to turn it down. If you want to impress someone with your audiophile knowledge and say the highs or lows or middles are not to your liking, feel free. As for me, I think it overall sounds absolutely great, it does double duty as both a soundbar and an Echo, and the price point is absolutely right for either of those things. I love it, and am thinking hard about getting another for my bedroom TV once my credit cards stop crying over the damage I did to them during Christmas! LOL!!

So I own this and an Apple HomePod. I A-B this right next to an Apple HomePod in my house with my music. The Apple HomePod is definitely higher fidelity, but the HomePod is a one trick pony in my opinion and there are a few other disappointing elements of the HomePod. The Echo Studio is all around the better “smart” speaker especially if you already have echo or Alexa infrastructure in your house. The sound is fairly solid; after some EQ in the app you can get it to perform. I think the sound has a better gelling compression as well so songs sound more stereo. There is a 3D mode that works on Amazon music that adds enough separation and sparkle to sound more like a HomePod if you really like a lot of clarity in your home audio. I saved this for last, I was a sound engineer for over a decade and I think both speakers are pretty good for a single speaker that auto adjusts to your environment. You’ll be pretty happy to save the space and have the assistant with either. In the end I go with Echo studio because it can connect to Bluetooth which allows me to stream anything I want to it. The HomePod only allows Airplay.

Was really excited to get these but amazon created a device that is only fully usable if you use only amazon apps and devices. If you like other music apps or other manufacturers this is not for you. Sadly returned after only an hour of disappointing use. I can say the sound was amazing but with only amazon options they might as well be an AM radio’s.

Voice recognition is terrible. Most of the time Alexa only hears her name and nothing else. Set a timer? Be ready to say it 3 times. Want bluetooth off? 3rd time's the charm! The dot has it beat here and that's bad at 8x the cost.

Also drops bluetooth a lot and doesn't remember previous devices. Hard to play Spotify, constantly disconnects and switches to another device. Boots me and defaults to the PC a lot.

Sound quality is decent for what it is but I still prefer the top 2 JBL models for that. Plus they're portable... But really, if I want high fidelity I'll throw on a record or pop in an SACD disc. Takes a lot to impress me in this department and a $200 product ain't gonna hack it.

Remember the original Echo? They don't make 'em like they used to...

I have plenty of Echos in my house. I really didn’t need another one but I was looking for something to give me more bass when I play music through the whole house. I’ve tried placing this on a shelf, in an entertainment center and even just sitting on the floor. None of these places gave me the bass I was hoping for. Don’t get me wrong, this is an amazing echo device. The sound quality from the other speakers in this is great. If you were to pair this with another Studio I’m sure it’d sound amazing. My problem is, for the price, this is not worth it.

Welcome audio files May poo poo this unit I think it is fantastic for its ability to provide instant music on demand with a high quality of resolution. It may not be the best but it certainly in the ballpark for competition with Sonos Bose and the rest. I already had Alexa and various places the voice recognition was pretty good this one's even better. And I might add that the base is admirable as well. Lots of pretty good quality sound and functional capabilities with this unit. You might even buy another one for a bit more stereo sound.

As a sound designer, I spend a lot of time in front of high -end studio monitors. Can echo studio match them? Of course not, but then again, that is not the point (besides being economically impossible). The point is accurate reproduction of a mix, and this device does the job in a very pleasant and unassuming way. With six inch woofer and smartly positioned tweeters, it almost manages to create a stereo image while covering a full spectrum of frequency response. I would expect that paired with another echo studio it could sound better (and more accurate) than many low end, smaller studio monitors, and certainly better than “multimedia” monitors like Mackie CR series etc. The reason for this, besides pretty smart and good engineering, is a built in “room correction” that measures frequency response of your room and adapts echo’s output accordingly. In professional audio, we pay a lot of money for this kind of calibration, and here you get it as if it were nothing. All in all, for the price, this product is pretty amazing.

So far there is nothing to dislike about the Amazon Echo Studio. I have an Amazon Echo and have been happy with its performance since I purchased it several years ago. However the sound quality and sometimes the voice recognition was not the best. It was located in a large open area that includes a large kitchen and living area. The Amazon Echo Studio now occupies that space and eradicates the issues I had with the smaller Amazon echo. Voice recognition is exceptional. I can in a normal tone and volume instruct the Amazon Studio from another room and always get the correct response. And the sound is extraordinary for a single speaker unit. I do not have the time to listen to a lot of music, but when I do the sounds from the Echo Studio are excellent. Aesthetically the unit fits the décor of my living area perfectly. The Echo Studio flawlessly connected to all my in house devices and makes life much easier for me. Very happy with the unit.

Had to be defective. Only tweeter worked. Took 5 shots to get it paired to my WiFi as it was sitting right next to working Firestick 4K. Noticed tiny sound. Called tech support and they had me update software, reset, etc. Nothing worked. Sent back for full refund.

My original order 2 weeks ago stated I would not receive the unil Jan 11th. Got it on Dec 24. I assume it was a defective unit or damaged in transit. The shipping box had no air cushions or anything and the echo studio inner box has no foam or anything.
Clear sound, great bass

I really wanted to be wowed by this speaker. I mainly purchased it to substitute for the television speakers. The speaker sounds really good, wide range with good dynamics, but as a point source. I expected to hear sounds emanate from the sides of the room, above me and behind me. For me, it doesn't. Now, if I didn't have these expectations I likely would be satisfied. I also would be really grateful if the speaker had a digital output to pass high resolution music from the speaker to an audio amplifier to appreciate fully Amazon Music UHD music.

Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
 I bought these after reading about the Alexa Home theater (search youtube) using these and a fire tv cube. From the standpoint of just being single speakers they sound decent. However, I dont believe decent enough to be worth their price point. I got two of them and have them paired to have 3d mode and have Dolby atmos. The 3d music is cool but can only be done with a handful of amazon tracks. The Atmos for movies and tv is okay (not amazing) and again it only works with certain media through certain apps. Otherwise they are connected speakers. I had a couple of bookshelf speakers attached before that I think did just as well. Getting the home theater through Alexa setup was a chore. I work in tech and have done home theater for a while and I gave up. My wife ended up figuring out after re-doing it countless times. I also wish I could get audio input through something other than wifi. When we swich inputs on our tv we have no connected audio (more a fire tv issue) but worth noting.

They are nice because everything is connected through alexa, but for a premium speaker they aren't amazing and the setup was just Alright. That song above is recorded through my iphone 12 (mini) and that is one of Amazon's HD tracks. (for reference). I have run FLAC files through it via plex on my fire cube and the sound was about the same.

Sound quality of this speaker is actually very good when used in a set with a sub. That being said, is a pretty big investment and leap of faith to put into an Amazon made item. Well, not even one year into my purchase, second studio speaker is dead, (loose connection internally). New one is on the way under warranty. Overall pretty disappointed in durability of this speaker.

Not too much to add to add to the other 215 reviews. I cant explain the excellent quality any better than what has already been said. Very high-end audio device. Produces a very wide frequency response at low and hi volume levels. When placed correctly in a room the sound is expansive and wraps around you due to is well thought design, teamed up with the SUB you will have audiophile quality sound. PRICE is very comfortable for what your getting in quality. If you demand Hi fidelity sound , here you go...wont go wrong. Nice Job. Amazon!

I am in a 2-bedroom house. My Christmas-day Echo Studio is 12 feet from my Night Ranger router. My iPhone gets a 100% signal across the street from my home and in my detached garage 75 feet from my home. The Echo Studio barely sees the WiFi. 9 out of 10 times, it will not connect. When it does, it drops off over and over. Very frustrating to be trouble shooting Echo most of Christmas afternoon. Never had this issue with my first-gen Echo. Just had tech support hook back up. It's already dropped off again.

Firstly, since I already has the Alexa app on my phone, it took less than a minute to fire it up.
